contentrichtext.text: [[File:Portrait_of_an_Olivetan_Monk_-_Battista_Franco_(attributed).jpg|thumb|Depiction of an Olivetan monk, 16th century]] The '''Olivetans''', or the '''Order of Our Lady of Mount Olivet''', are a monastic order formally recognised in 1344. They have formed the '''Olivetan Congregation''' within the [[Benedictine Confederation]] since 1960. ==History== The '''Order of Our Lady of Mount Olivet''' is a small [[Roman Catholic]] order, founded in 1313 by [[Bernardo Tolomei]] (born Giovanni Tolomei) along with two of his friends from the noble families of [[Siena]], Patrizio Patrizi and Ambrogio [[Piccolomini]]. They initially lived as hermits in the "savage waste of [[Accona]]". The building of the monastery here began with the [[approbation]] of the foundation charter by [[Guido Tarlati]], [[bishop of Arezzo]] (26 March 1319). The name "Olivetan" comes from the name of the order's original hermitage, called '''Monte Oliveto''' in honour of Christ’s Passion. The monastery later became known as "[[Monte Oliveto Maggiore]]" ("greater") to distinguish it from successive foundations at [[Florence]], [[San Gimignano]], [[Naples]] and elsewhere. It is still the mother house of the order or congregation. See [[Monte Oliveto Maggiore]] for the main article on the monastery. After the arrival of a number of new followers, the nascent community adopted the [[Rule of St. Benedict]] and was recognised by Pope [[Clement VI]] in 1344. ==Benedict XVI== Despite [[prophecy|modern myths]] surrounding [[Prophecy of the Popes|the prophesies]] attributed to Catholic mystic [[Saint Malachy]] (but which critics see as a c1590 [[Prophecy_of_the_Popes#History|forgery]]), there is no connection between the Olivetan Order and the Pope elected in 2005, [[Pope Benedict XVI|Benedict XVI]] (supposedly the second-last Pope, 'Glory of the Olive', according to [[Prophecy of the Popes|the prophesies]]). While it is true that the Olivetan congregation is considered a [[Benedictine_Confederation#Congregations_of_Benedictine_Monks|branch]] of the [[Benedictine]] order, the same can be said of the many other monastic congregations that follow the Rule of St. Benedict. ==Today== The Olivetan monks rule [[Bec Abbey]] in [[France]], as well as other houses in England, USA, Italy, Brazil, Guatemala, Israel and South Korea. ==External links== *[http://www.monteolivetomaggiore.it/ Monte Oliveto Maggiore] {{it icon}} *[http://www.osb.org/intl/confed/confed.html Order of St. Benedict] ==References== * Giuseppe Picasso.
